Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Integrating genetics, life history, and morphology to understand the diversification of an enigmatic metazoan lineage
Award.AbstractNarration:
Rotifers are critical members of freshwater communities because of their important roles in energy and nutrient cycling. Rotifers have also proven to be valuable models for aging and toxicology studies, and are a key early diverging lineage for understanding the pattern of evolution within the animal clade. Despite this importance, rotifer species remain difficult to identify and few phylogenetic relationships within the clade are well supported. This collaborative effort linking researchers at the University of Texas El Paso, University of Massachusetts Lowell and Ripon College will increase phylogenetic and taxonomic resolution within phylum Rotifera by using a combination of advanced molecular and morphological techniques. This research will result in a new phylogenetic classification for the clade, in addition to insights into the rates of molecular evolution and the rates and drivers of cryptic speciation within the rotifer lineage.

The project will provide scientific training focused on rotifer systematics to graduate and undergraduate students at each of the three collaborating institutions. An undergraduate laboratory module, newly designed museum exhibit, and scientific workshops will all help disseminate the results broadly. The public will be able to access an interactive tutorial and key to rotifer species, plus other results from the project via the Encyclopedia of Life website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This is a summary of the outcomes for a collaborative research project entitled “Integrating genetics, life history, and morphology to understand the diversification of an enigmatic metazoan lineage.” This project took place at three universities across the country (El Paso, TX; Ripon, WI; Lowell, MA). The project had four goals.

The first goal was to investigate the evolutionary relationships and the evolution of life histories among a group of freshwater invertebrates, the Rotifera and in particular sessile and colonial species. Rotifers are ubiquitous in freshwater systems and play important roles in nutrient cycling and species interactions. They are also used as models for studying evolution of life history, the evolution of sex, dispersal, aging, and for environmental toxicology. To accomplish this goal, we obtained thousands of DNA sequences from a broad representation of rotifers with diverse life styles and constructed phylogenetic trees of their relationships. We produced a working phylogeny of the entire group. During this process, many new species were identified based on DNA taxonomy, and we are still finding more as data continue to be analyzed. Species descriptions of some species have been submitted for publication. We also found that genome size is smaller in free-swimming species when compared to those that have a sessile life history.

The second goal was to investigate morphology, feeding, and life cycle in a phylogenetic context. As part of this goal we studied the jaws, neuroanatomy, tubes (morphology and composition), and life history of several species. Some examples of our findings include that the nervous system is somewhat re-modeled during metamorphosis from free swimming larvae into sessile adults in several taxa. When looking at life history among lineages of the rotifer Collotheca ornata, we found differences in body sizes and time to metamorphosis. This demonstrates that genetic differentiation is accompanied by ecological differentiation.

The third goal was advance infrastructure of scientific training in sessile rotifer taxonomy. To meet this goal, we developed and published a taxonomic key to one sessile genus. We also refined several keys to the Rotifera, and more are being developed. We also studied morphological features of some of the sessile taxa as noted above.

The fourth goal was to advance scientific training in rotifer taxonomy. This was accomplished by have a large training component. Over 20 undergraduates (61% female; 73.5% underrepresented minority), four Masters students (50% female; 100% Hispanic; 2 graduated, 2 are in progress), and five doctoral students (40% female; 60% Hispanic; 1 graduated, 4 are in progress) were trained in molecular systematics and ecology during the four years of this project. In addition, students received cross-training by engaging in research visits to the laboratories of the other faculty on the team.

This project resulted in 16 publications in peer-reviewed journals, with another 8 submitted. In addition, one book chapter was published. Of these publications, 10 have student co-authors, and several of them are collaborative efforts among the students and faculty investigators of the grant. A total of 82 presentations (62 with student authors or co-authors) were made at local, national, and international conferences reporting aspects of findings of this project. A museum exhibit on Invertebrate Jaws was prepared. This exhibit featured jaws from a variety of invertebrates but had a special focus on the complex jaws of rotifers. Over 2300 visitors, including >800 school children, visited the exhibit. Many public lectures were given as part of this project including talks at state parks, environmental groups, student groups, and the general public. An international symposium was organized by the three grant recipient and had over 95 attendees including researchers from Mexico, China, Japan, South Korea, UK, Germany, Israel, Italy, Croatia, Belarus, and Spain. Many of the presentations pertained to funded project.
